TEXT.English: [TAB]Grasslands are areas where the vegetation is dominated by grasses and other herbaceous plants. Grasslands occur naturally on all continents except Antarctica. In temperate latitudes native grasslands are dominated by perennial bunch grass species, whereas in warmer climates annual species form a greater component of the vegetation.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]草原是指植被以草和其他草本植物为主的地区。除南极洲外，所有大陆都有天然草地。在温带地区，天然草地主要由多年生丛生草种组成，而在温暖的气候条件下，一年生草种是植被的主要组成部分。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Plains are a big flat areas of land with little to no forestation, and often characterized by a semi-arid continental climate. Steppes and prairies are varieties of plains.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]平原是一片大而平坦的土地，几乎没有森林，通常以半干旱的大陆性气候为特征。大草原和大草原是各种各样的平原。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A desert is a landscape or region that receives an extremely low amount of precipitation, less than enough to support growth of most plants. Deserts are often composed of sand and rocky surfaces. Sand dunes called ergs and stony surfaces called hamada compose a minority of desert surfaces. Exposures of rocky terrain are typical, and reflect minimal soil development and sparseness of vegetation. Deserts take up about 20% of the Earth's land surface.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]沙漠是指降雨量极低、不足以支持大多数植物生长的景观或区域。沙漠通常由沙子和岩石组成。沙丘被称为ergs，岩石表面被称为hamada组成了沙漠表面的一小部分。岩石地形的暴露是典型的，反映了最小的土壤发育和植被稀疏。沙漠占地球地表的20%左右。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Tundra is a terrain where the tree growth is hindered by low temperatures, short growing seasons, and sometimes permafrost subsoil. Vegetation is sparse and composed of dwarf shrubs, sedges and grasses, mosses, and lichens. Scattered trees grow in some tundra. The boundary between tundra and forest is known as the tree line.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]冻土带是一种树木生长受到低温、生长季节短，有时还受到永久冻土的阻碍的地形。植被稀疏，由矮小灌木、莎草和草、苔藓和地衣组成。一些苔原上长着零散的树。冻土带和森林之间的界线被称为树线。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A mountain is a large landform that stretches above the surrounding land in a limited area, usually in the form of a peak. They are usually formed by movement and intersection of tectonic plates. Tall mountains reach into the colder layers of the atmosphere where they are subject to glaciation and erosion through frost action. They have different climatic conditions at the top than at the base, meaning different life zones at different altitudes.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]山脉是指在有限的区域内，在周围土地之上延伸的一种大地形，通常以山峰的形式出现。它们通常是由板块运动和交叉形成的。高大的山脉延伸到较冷的大气层，在那里它们受到冰层作用和侵蚀。它们在顶部的气候条件不同于在底部，这意味着在不同的高度有不同的生活区。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A hill is a landform that extends above the surrounding terrain, with or without a distinct summit. Hills may form through a number of geomorphic phenomena: faulting, erosion of larger landforms such as mountains, and the deposition of sediment by glaciers. The distinction between a hill and a mountain is unclear and largely subjective, but a hill is generally somewhat lower and less steep than a mountain.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]山丘是指在周围地形之上延伸的地形，有或没有明显的山顶。山丘可能是通过许多地貌现象形成的：断层作用、山体等较大地貌的侵蚀和冰川沉积。山和山之间的区别不清楚，而且很大程度上是主观的，但山通常比山低一些，不那么陡峭。

TEXT.English: [TAB]The coastline is where the land meets the sea or ocean. A precise line that can be called a coastline cannot be determined due to the dynamic nature of tides. The term "coastal zone" can be used instead, which is a spatial zone where interaction of the sea and land processes occurs.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]海岸线是陆地与海洋的交汇处。由于潮汐的动态性质，无法确定一条可以称为海岸线的精确线。可以使用“海岸带”一词，这是一个发生海陆相互作用的空间带。

TEXT.English: [TAB]An ocean is a major body of saline water, and a principal component of the hydrosphere. Approximately 71% of the Earth's surface is covered by ocean, a continuous body of water that is customarily divided into several principal oceans and smaller seas.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]海洋是咸水的主体，是水圈的主要组成部分。地球表面约71%被海洋覆盖，海洋是一个连续的水体，通常被分成几个主要海洋和较小的海洋。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A jungle is an area of land in the tropics overgrown with dense vegetation. The undergrowth in a rainforest is restricted in many areas by the poor penetration of sunlight to ground level. This makes it easy to walk through undisturbed, mature rainforest. If the leaf canopy is destroyed or thinned, the ground beneath is soon colonized by a dense, tangled growth of vines, shrubs and small trees, called a jungle. There are two types of rainforest, tropical rainforest and temperate rainforest.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]丛林是指热带地区植被茂密的土地。雨林中的灌木丛在许多地区由于阳光对地面的渗透性差而受到限制。这使得我们可以很容易地穿过未受干扰的成熟雨林。如果叶冠被破坏或变薄，下面的地面很快就会被茂密、缠绕的藤蔓、灌木和小树所占据，称为丛林。有两种类型的雨林，热带雨林和温带雨林。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A floodplain, or flood plain, is a flat or nearly flat land adjacent to a stream or river that stretches from the banks of its channel to the base of the enclosing valley walls and experiences flooding during periods of high discharge. It includes the floodway, which consists of the stream channel and adjacent areas that carry flood flows, and the flood fringe, which are areas covered by the flood, but which do not experience a strong current.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]漫滩，或漫滩，是指与河流或河流相邻的平坦或接近平坦的土地，从其河道的河岸延伸到封闭的谷壁底部，在高流量期间经历洪水。它包括由河道和承载洪水的邻近区域组成的防洪道，以及被洪水覆盖但不经历强流的洪水边缘区域。

TEXT.English: [TAB]An oasis is an isolated area of vegetation in a desert, typically surrounding a spring or similar water source. Oases also provide habitat for animals and even humans if the area is big enough. The location of oases has been of critical importance for trade and transportation routes in desert areas. Caravans must travel via oases so that supplies of water and food can be replenished. Thus, political or military control of an oasis has in many cases meant control of trade on a particular route.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]绿洲是沙漠中孤立的植被区域，通常围绕着泉水或类似的水源。如果面积足够大，绿洲也为动物甚至人类提供栖息地。绿洲的位置对于沙漠地区的贸易和运输路线至关重要。大篷车必须经过绿洲才能补充水和食物。因此，在许多情况下，对绿洲的政治或军事控制意味着对特定路线上的贸易的控制。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Fallout is the residual radioactive material propelled into the upper atmosphere following a nuclear blast or a nuclear reaction conducted in an unshielded facility, so called because it "falls out" of the sky after the explosion and shock wave have passed. It commonly refers to the radioactive dust and ash created when a nuclear weapon explodes, but this dust can also be originated in a damaged nuclear plant. This radioactive dust, consisting of material either directly vaporized by a nuclear blast or charged by exposure, is a highly dangerous kind of radioactive contamination. It can lead to the contamination of aquifers or soil and devastate the affected ecosystems years after the initial exposure.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]放射性尘埃是指核爆炸或在无屏蔽设施中进行核反应后进入上层大气的残余放射性物质，之所以称为放射性尘埃，是因为它在爆炸和冲击波经过后“从”天空中脱落。它通常是指核武器爆炸时产生的放射性尘埃和灰烬，但这种尘埃也可能起源于受损的核电站。这种放射性尘埃是一种高度危险的放射性污染，由核爆炸直接蒸发或暴露带电的物质组成。它可能会导致含水层或土壤的污染，并在最初暴露多年后破坏受影响的生态系统。

TEXT.English: [TAB]In low-lying terrain, where water is plentiful and the water table lies close to the surface, it is common for the land to be muddy and heavily overgrown with vegetation. This type of terrain can be known as a swamp, bog, fen, marsh, or wetlands.[PARAGRAPH:1]Human interaction with swamps is complex. Swampy ground is difficult and dangerous to move through, often riddled with quicksand and bodies of water that make land vehicles useless, movement on foot difficult, and even small boat traffic a challenge. It is usually unsafe to build on wet ground, as heavy buildings will simply sink into the mud, never to be seen again. Construction on such unstable terrain requires the use of piles sunk deep into the swamp, and even then is often uneconomical for use on a large scale. Wetlands also serve as breeding grounds for insects that can carry diseases such as malaria.[PARAGRAPH:1]For all these reasons, many civilizations have attempted to drain the wetlands around them of water, so that the land can be used for other purposes. This often causes environmental damage and can destroy the livelihood of the inhabitants.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]地势低洼，水量充沛，地下水位接近地表，土地泥泞，植被茂密。这种地形可以称为沼泽、沼泽、沼泽、沼泽或湿地。[段落：1]人类与沼泽的相互作用是复杂的。沼泽地很难通过，而且很危险，经常布满流沙和水体，使得陆上车辆毫无用处，步行很难移动，甚至小船交通也很困难。在潮湿的地面上建造通常是不安全的，因为重型建筑只会沉入泥中，再也看不见了。在这样不稳定的地形上施工，需要使用深陷沼泽的桩，即便如此，大规模使用也往往不经济。湿地也是携带疟疾等疾病的昆虫的繁殖地。[第1段]由于所有这些原因，许多文明试图将周围湿地的水排干，以便土地可以用于其他用途。这常常造成环境破坏，并可能破坏居民的生活。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ice sheets are masses of glacial ice that cover land in Earth's polar regions. They currently exist in just Antarctica and Greenland and hold over 90% of all fresh water on Earth. Even larger ice sheets existed in the geological past, covering much of Europe and the Americas.
TEXT.Chinese: [表]冰原是覆盖地球极地陆地的大量冰川。它们目前只存在于南极洲和格陵兰岛，占据地球上90%以上的淡水。更大的冰盖存在于过去的地质时期，覆盖了欧洲和美洲的大部分地区。

TEXT.English: [TAB]A forest is an area with a high density of trees. There are many definitions for forest, based on the various criteria. These plant communities cover approximately 9.4% of the Earth's surface (or 30% of total land area), though they once covered much more (about 50% of total land area), in many different regions and function as habitats for organisms, hydrologic flow modulators, and soil conservers, constituting one of the most important aspects of the Earth's biosphere. Although a forest is classified primarily by trees a forest ecosystem is defined intrinsically with additional species such as fungi.
TEXT.Chinese: [TAB]森林是树木密集的地区。根据各种标准，对森林有许多定义。这些植物群落覆盖了地球表面约9.4%（或总陆地面积的30%），尽管它们曾经覆盖了许多不同的地区（约占总陆地面积的50%），并作为生物、水文流量调节器和土壤保护者的栖息地，构成地球生物圈最重要的方面之一。虽然森林主要由树木分类，但森林生态系统本质上是由真菌等附加物种定义的。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Not all ocean waters make for smooth sailing. Wherever there is an island chain, there will be seamounts and rises that only *almost* break the surface of the water, creating patches of extremely shallow seabed studded with rocks that can tear out the bottom of even the sturdiest ships. Reefs are hazardous for navigation, especially in ships designed for deep water sailing. Travel through reefs requires a skillful steersman and good charts - and even then, the patterns of sandbanks and coral formations in shoal waters can change unpredictably.[PARAGRAPH:1]In nautical terminology, a reef is a rock, sandbar, or other feature lying beneath the surface of the water (six fathoms or less beneath low water).[PARAGRAPH:1]Many reefs result from abiotic processes-deposition of sand, wave erosion planning down rock outcrops, and other natural processes-but the best-known reefs are the coral reefs of tropical waters developed through biotic processes dominated by corals and calcareous algae. Artificial reefs such as shipwrecks are sometimes created to enhance physical complexity on generally featureless sand bottoms in order to attract a diverse assemblage of organisms, especially fish.
TEXT.Chinese: 并非所有的海水都能使航行平稳。在任何有岛链的地方，都会有海山和海隆，它们几乎都会冲破水面，形成一片片极浅的海床，上面布满岩石，即使是最坚固的船只，也会撕裂船底。暗礁对航行是危险的，特别是在设计用于深水航行的船舶上。在暗礁中航行需要熟练的舵手和良好的海图――即使如此，浅滩水域的沙洲和珊瑚形成的模式也会发生不可预测的变化。[第1段]在航海术语中，暗礁是岩石、沙洲，或其他位于水面下的特征（在低水位下6英寻或更低）。[第1段]许多珊瑚礁是由非生物过程沉积的沙子、沿着岩石露头规划的波浪侵蚀和其他自然过程造成的，但最著名的珊瑚礁是通过生物过程主导的热带水域的珊瑚礁珊瑚和钙质藻类。为了吸引各种各样的生物，特别是鱼类，人们有时会在通常没有特色的沙底上建造一些人工珊瑚礁，例如沉船。

TEXT.English: [TAB]An island is any piece of sub-continental land that is surrounded by water. Very small islands such as emergent land features on atolls can be called islets, cays or keys. A grouping of geographically or geologically related islands is called an archipelago.
TEXT.Chinese: [标签]岛屿是指被水包围的任何一块次大陆陆地。非常小的岛屿，如环礁上的陆地地貌，可以称为小岛、珊瑚礁或珊瑚礁。一组地理上或地理上相关的岛屿被称为群岛。

TEXT.English: [TAB]Remnants of a long gone age, these Pyramids are truly spectacular. They might give inspiration to your population in the neighboring cities!
TEXT.Chinese: 【标签】古老的遗迹，这些金字塔真的很壮观。他们可能会给你在邻近城市的人口带来灵感！

TEXT.English: You have discovered a source of %s1_BonusName near %s2_CityName!
A source of %s1_resource near %s2_CityName has been exhausted!
With the removal of the forest, the source of %s1_resource has been exhausted!
TEXT.Chinese: 随着森林的砍伐殆尽, %s1_resource 已经荒弃!
